facts.text: The appellant is a partnership concern carrying on business in the manufacture of pharmaceutical products.

There was a gratuity scheme in force in the appellant-concern for a long time, modified by an award of the industrial tribunal dated August 18, 1952 (hereinafter called the Award), and since then the modified scheme has been in force.
The financial condition of the appellant deteriorated and consequently, it was compelled to retrench a number of workmen.

The appellant applied to the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India under s. 22 of the Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, No. XLVIII of 1950, for permission to retrench 89 workmen. The Appellate Tribunal granted permission for retrenchment of 75 workmen only.
After obtaining permission, the appellant retrenched the 75 workmen and paid them compensation as provided in s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 (hereinafter called the Act).
A dispute was raised by the retrenched workmen through the union in existence in the appellant-concern for gratuity on retrenchment under the Award.

The dispute was referred to the Second Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, on March 23, 1956, for adjudication in the terms: 'Whether the seventy-five retrenched employees (as per attached list) are entitled to gratuity in addition to retrenchment benefits?'

The Industrial Tribunal concluded that the retrenched workmen were only entitled to relief as provided under s. 25F of the Act and were not entitled to any gratuity under the Award over and above the compensation payable under the Act.

The workmen appealed to the Labour Appellate Tribunal, which allowed the appeal, holding that the workmen were entitled to gratuity under the Award, as gratuity benefit therein was not a retrenchment benefit.
The appellant applied for special leave to appeal to the Supreme Court, which was granted.

The Award provides a gratuity scheme for cases of retrenchment or termination of service by the company for any reason other than misconduct or for cases of resignation with the consent of the management, up to a maximum of 15 months basic pay, with qualifying service of one year, based on average of last 12 months basic pay; no gratuity before one year or for misconduct; on death, to widow/children/dependents.

legal_issues.text: Whether the retrenched workmen are entitled under the Award to gratuity provided therein in addition to retrenchment benefit under s. 25F of the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: The gratuity under the Award for retrenchment is nothing more or less than compensation on account of retrenchment, and workmen are not entitled to it in addition to s. 25F compensation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 25F, s. 25J, Chapter VA of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947; s. 2(oo)

respondent_arguments.text: The workmen were entitled to gratuity under the Award, as gratuity benefit therein was not a retrenchment benefit.

court_reasoning.text: The Award is a composite scheme providing for what is termed 'gratuity' under three conditions: retrenchment, termination for reason other than misconduct, resignation with consent. Though called gratuity, payment on retrenchment is really compensation on account of retrenchment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The name given to the payment is not material; it is the nature of the payment that matters.

court_reasoning.text: A retrenched workman could claim under the Award only on account of retrenchment, not other conditions. On fair construction, it is only compensation for retrenchment, not gratuity properly so called.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Award covers retrenchment as defined in s. 2(oo), and also excepted cases like resignation and termination other than misconduct.

court_reasoning.text: Chapter VA (ss. 25F, 25J) added in 1953 provides uniform minimum retrenchment compensation. s. 25J(1) overrides inconsistent provisions, but proviso protects rights under awards/contracts for more than s. 25F; not intended for double payment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature did not intend double compensation, once under Act and once under scheme.

court_reasoning.text: Gratuity on retrenchment under Award has everything to do with s. 25F compensation; not different. No justification for compelling payment twice if scheme provides for retrenchment as in s. 2(oo).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Would be different if gratuity different in nature from s. 25F compensation.

court_reasoning.text: s. 25F provisions better than Award for retrenchment; workmen entitled to s. 25F only, not both.

holdings.text: Gratuity provided in the Award on retrenchment is nothing more or less than retrenchment compensation under s. 25F; workmen entitled only to whichever is more advantageous per s. 25J, and here s. 25F is better; not entitled to both.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Indian Hume Pipe Company Limited v. Its Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: General question considered therein; special considerations may arise on terms of agreements or awards in particular cases.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines retrenchment; provides uniform minimum compensation on retrenchment overriding inconsistent provisions but protecting superior award rights; no double payment intended.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Permission for retrenchment sought and obtained thereunder.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; decision of Labour Appellate Tribunal set aside; decision of Industrial Tribunal restored. Workmen not entitled to gratuity under Award in addition to s. 25F compensation already paid.
outcome.relief_granted: None further; confirmation that s. 25F payment suffices.

key_quotes.text: The name given to the payment is, however, not material and it is the nature of the payment that has to be looked into.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle distinguishing form from substance in classifying payments.

key_quotes.text: It was not the intention of the legislature that a workman on retrenchment should get compensation twice, i.e., once under the Act and once under the scheme in force providing for retrenchment compensation, by whatever name the payment might have been called.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects double recovery; interprets legislative intent behind Chapter VA.

key_quotes.text: We see no justification for compelling that payment twice over, once under s. 25F and again under the scheme in force in the concern.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Direct holding against additional payment under the Award.
